title: Peyronie’s Disease Regenerative Plan
tagline: Straighten, Soften, and Strengthen Without Surgery
description: Doctor-led combination of PRP, shockwave, traction, and topical therapy that repairs penile curvature and discomfort.
longDescription: Peyronie’s disease forms fibrotic plaques under the penile skin, causing curvature, pain, and anxiety. Our regenerative protocol combines platelet-rich plasma (P-Shot®), focused shockwave therapy, traction devices, and prescription topicals to soften plaques, improve symmetry, and restore confidence.\n\nRather than relying on surgery or off-label injections alone, we treat the root causes: inflammation, scar tissue, and restricted blood flow. Each plan is customised after Doppler imaging and curvature measurement so you understand every milestone toward straighter, pain-free erections.

overview.content: We start with penile Doppler, curvature photography, and symptom scoring. Treatment blends dual-spin PRP to stimulate collagen remodelling, LI-ESWT to break down plaques, and traction/restore devices to encourage straight healing. Anti-inflammatory prescriptions and topical compounding creams reduce pain while supplements optimise nitric oxide and scar prevention.

faq.question: Do I need surgery for Peyronie’s?
faq.answer: Most men do not. Our regenerative approach can significantly reduce curvature and pain before surgical options are considered.

faq.question: Is collagenase (Xiaflex) included?
faq.answer: We focus on PRP, shockwave, and traction. If collagenase is appropriate, we can refer you to a surgical colleague.

faq.question: How soon can I resume intercourse?
faq.answer: Usually within 24 hours of PRP and immediately after shockwave. We provide personalised guidance.

faq.question: Will traction hurt?
faq.answer: We teach comfortable usage and gradually increase tension. Most men adapt within a few days.

faq.question: What if my curvature is severe?
faq.answer: We work alongside urologists for hybrid plans. Even with >60° curvature, regenerative therapy can improve outcomes pre- or post-surgery.
